I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the additional financing of the Panj–Amu River Basin 
Sector Project. 1 
 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the original project on 26 October 2016. 2 
2. 
The  project  was  designed  to  increase  agricultural  productivity  in  the  Panj–Amu  River  Basin  in 
northeast Afghanistan by improving access to and use of water and building climate resilience 
through  the  implementation  of  watershed  natural  resource  management  plans.  The  project’s 
impact  is  per  capita  income  increased  and  poverty  among  rural  and  pastoral  communities 
reduced. The current project has three outputs (para. 7). The additional financing will expand the 
scope of output 3 to include additional watershed subprojects. Panj–Amu River Basin is a major 
production center for wheat, rice, vegetables, and fruit. Subproject investments will target water 
harvesting  to  increase  water  availability  by  increasing  underground  water  recharge,  improving 
access,  and  reducing  water  runoff  and  flood  damage.  The  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President for the ongoing project is accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
The  proposed  project  meets  the  eligibility  criteria  for  additional  financing.  The  original 
project’s rating is on-track. The project outcomes will be achieved by the original project’s closing 
date of 31 May 2023. Physical progress was about 47% 3 as of 31 August 2020 (elapsed time: 
55%).  Cumulative  contract  awards  were  $42.31  million  (57%)  while  disbursements  were 
$13.76 million (18%). Outputs 2 and 3 of the original project are progressing well. Output 1 initial 
delays  were  rectified.  The  original  project  complies  with  fiduciary  requirements,  environmental 
and social safeguard policies, and is successful in risk management. The midterm review found 
no  issues  with  grant  covenant  compliance,  except  for  the  covenant  on  the  preparation  and 
issuance of an operation and maintenance (O&M) policy. 
 
Responding  to  the  severe  climate  events—namely,  a  large-scale  drought  in  2018  and 
4. 
severe floods in 2019—the government prioritized water harvesting. 4 As per the national water 
harvesting  program,  the  National  Water  Affairs  Regulation  Authority  (NWARA) 5 identified  and 
prepared prefeasibility studies on 334 subprojects, with many being small to medium scale (8–
11,500  hectares  [ha]).  Given  the  good  progress  under  output  3  (para.  8),  the  government 
requested ADB support to expand its watershed interventions in the Panj–Amu River Basin. The 
additional  financing  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  Afghanistan, 
2017−2021. 6  It  is  included  in  ADB’s  country  operation  business  plan  for  Afghanistan, 
2020−2022. 7 It  also  supports  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  operational  priorities  of  addressing  poverty 
and  gender  equality,    tackling  climate  change  and  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,

 2 

promoting rural development and food security, and strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity. 8 
 
5. 
The Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) epidemic resulted in a contraction in the economy, 
with increased levels of unemployment especially in the informal sector in urban and rural areas, 
and increased poverty and food insecurity. The government is tackling the COVID-19 epidemic 
with a national COVID-19 program and targeted social welfare support.  
 
This project is relevant and appropriate in the current Afghanistan COVID-19 environment, 
6. 
as it is focused on smallholder households and local communities, with activities that will generate 
improved household incomes, livelihoods and employment. The project will have a direct local 
impact  with  improved  livelihoods,  decreasing  poverty  and  food  insecurity.  The  employment 
generated may benefit those workers who have lost employment in off-farm activities that have 
closed  due  to  COVID-19.  The  improved  livelihoods  will  enable  households  to  access  health 
services if they are affected by COVID-19. 
 
The additional financing will enhance resilience of watersheds to disaster and climate risks 
7. 
by adding 77 watershed subprojects under output 3. 9 The new activities will be completed within 
the original project period ending 31 May 2023. The additional financing modality is appropriate 10 
since  the  activities  supplement  activities  of  the  original  project.  The  original  project’s  sector 
modality, design, and implementation arrangements can also be used efficiently.  
 
8. 
The  project  follows  the  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations  and  enhanced  project 
delivery  approaches  and  includes:  (i)  sector  financing,  which  allows  flexibility  in  subproject 
selection and implementation given security concerns; (ii) streamlined project management office 
structure,  which  helps  long-term  programmatic  sector  interventions;  and  (iii)  community 
participation  in  procurement  and  involvement  of  local  elders,  which  minimizes  interruption 
(including security) of work. The project readiness is enhanced by the advance contracting. 
 
B. 
 
9. 
The project is aligned with the following impacts: per capita income increased and poverty 
among rural and pastoral communities reduced. 11 The project will have the following outcome: 
agricultural  productivity  in  the  Panj–Amu  River  Basin  increased. 12 The  project  outputs  are  (i) 
water  allocation  and  availability  improved,  (ii)  command  areas  enhanced;  and  (iii)  watersheds 
properly managed and protected. The impact, outcome, and outputs will remain unchanged for 
the overall project.  
 
10. 
Under  output  3  of  the  original  project,  activities  are  being  undertaken  for 26  watershed 
subprojects in three provinces (Badakhshan, Kunduz, and Takhar). Details are provided in the 
Summary of Project Performance. 13 With the additional financing, the project will expand activities 
to  an  additional  77  watershed  subprojects  in  the  existing  three  project  provinces  and  in  six 
additional provinces: Samangan, Baghlan, Bamiyan, Panjshir, Parwan, and Wardak. Forty-two of 
the  subprojects  will  involve  small  investments  (less  than  $100,000)  and  35  will  involve

11. 
The forestry and rangeland protection target under output 3 will be increased from 10,000 
ha to 27,760 ha. Activities under the additional subprojects will include (i) installation of physical 
infrastructure and application of bioengineering (revegetation and reforestation) to improve water 
availability to rural households for irrigation and other uses, increase recharge, and reduce runoff 
and  sedimentation;  and  (ii)  preparation  of  watershed  resource  management  plans,  with 
community-based  organization  engagement  at  subproject  sites  to  be  developed  through  water 
users  associations  (WUAs)  and  community  development  councils. 15  Staff  training  will  be 
expanded to cover the new subproject areas. Training will target river basin and sub-river basin 
authority staff, local NWARA staff, and departments of agriculture, irrigation, and livestock (DAILs) 
staff. The training will enable staff to become master trainers to train communities. 
 
12. 
As  a  result  of  the  change  in  scope  to  output  3,  one  of  the  project’s  original  outcome 
indicator targets will change: the target command area (irrigated agricultural land) for the overall 
project will expand from 74,500 ha to 146,900 ha. 
 
C. 
 
ADB’s  value  addition  is  in  implementing  climate  adaptation  systems.  This  is  based  on 
13. 
watershed land improvements through flood management and improved irrigation and drainage, 
which will improve rural livelihoods (including of women) and food security and reduce poverty. 
ADB  support  will  also  target  sustainable  O&M  systems  and  building  government  and  local 
institutional capacity. The project is innovative in applying an integrated sustainable approach to 
climate change and disaster risk management in upper watersheds. Subproject interventions will 
increase  access  to  water  (e.g.,  water  storage  ponds,  check  dams),  provide  improvements  to 
precipitation  infiltration  and  recharge,  and  reduce  soil  erosion  and  landslides  by  restoring  the 
original  vegetation.  Technical  packages  and  natural  resource  management  plans  will  be 
developed  for  each  selected  subproject  site  and  adaptation  measures  adopted.  It  will  build  on 
ADB’s in-country extensive engagement in water resource management and rural development. 16  
 
D.

Summary of Assessment 
The project classification is high climate risk.a A climate and disaster risk assessment and 
management report was prepared. All subprojects will be screened for climate and disaster 
risks  and  will  incorporate  risk-reduction  measures.  The  additional  financing  will  use 
subproject watershed designs and approaches that have proven effective under the original 
project, and are within the capacity of local community organizations.b The interventions will 
increase resilience to potential climate change impacts. They will increase water retention, 
and water access for households, irrigation and livestock uses, and water recharge. Slope 
stabilization with revegetation and reforestation will reduce soil loss and flood damage. 
The  additional  financing  will  generate  significant  financial  and  economic  benefits  at  the 
watershed and household levels. The analysis of two representative subprojects indicates 
that  the  investments  will  be  economically  and  financially  viable,  and  directly  generate 
increased levels of on-farm employment and incremental returns at the household level and 
increase off-farm  rural  employment. The  economic  internal rates of  return  of  14.1% and 
31.7% for the two subprojects are above the opportunity cost of capital of 9%. 
The local community organizations that will be implementing the subproject interventions 
(in  watershed  resource  management  planning  and  bioengineering)  will  achieve  higher 
productivity  and  incremental  returns.  Higher  returns  and  improved  livelihoods  provide 
incentives for farm households to adopt sustainable O&M systems, including desilting and 
sedimentation removal on an annual basis. The government will ensure that, for structures 
beyond  the  capacity  of  community-based  O&M,  adequate  funds  are  allocated  from  the 
government’s budget to finance the O&M activities of SBAs. For community-based O&M, 
the government will ensure that pre-construction O&M agreements are signed before any 
watershed and/or irrigation works start. SBAs and WUAs will sign handover agreements 
with community development councils and other community organizations before any civil 
works are commissioned. These agreements will also cover the commitments for O&M. 
As per NWARA’s financial management assessment there are no significant risks related 
to project management. Nevertheless, the over-all pre-mitigation financial management risk 
of NWARA is substantial. NWARA project management offices are experienced with ADB 
projects. Under the original project, audited financial statements are timely submitted as per 
the auditing standards acceptable to ADB, and internal audit reports are submitted annually 
to  ADB.  The  procurement  risk  classification  is  assessed  as  substantial;  procurement 
specialists and staff under the original project will be engaged to enhance IA’s procurement 
capacity. All procurement and recruitment of consultants under the ADB grant will be carried

23. 
The  government  and  MOF  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement 
as described in detail in the PAM and in the grant document. The government and MOF have 
agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the grant agreement. 
 
24. 
Operation and maintenance. The government will ensure that, for structures outside the 
capacity of community-based O&M, adequate funds are allocated from the government’s budget 
to  finance  the  O&M  activities  of  sub-basin  authorities  (SBAs).  This  will  include  funds  for  the 
efficient  operation  of  sluice  gates  in  larger  structures.  For  community-based  O&M,  the 
government  will  ensure  that  pre-construction  O&M  agreements  are  signed  before  starting  any 
watershed  and/or  irrigation  works.  SBAs  and  WUAs  will  sign  handover  agreements  with 
community development councils and other community organizations before any civil works are 
commissioned.  These  agreements  will  also  cover  the  commitments  for  O&M  of  check  dams, 
including desilting and sedimentation removal. These will also be applicable for WUAs and the 
O&M and cleaning of offtakes. For other watershed management planning and bioengineering 
works,  such  agreements  will  be  signed  between  the  SBAs  and  the  respective  community 
organizations to ensure long-term watershed sustainability.

terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant
